angle.headline: The 'Hard Perimeter' Supply Chain Crisis
angle.angle: The Tasman Drive lockdown isn't just traffic; it's a logistics nightmare. I'm hearing that the 'Clean Zone' enforcement is so strict that three major food vendors were turned away this morning because their delivery trucks had non-sponsor logos. Operations managers are now frantically renting unbranded white vans to shuttle tons of perishables into the stadium before the hard freeze tonight.

specific_facts: Three major food vendors were denied entry at the Tasman Drive 'Checkpoint Charlie' this morning due to 'Ambush Marketing' violations on their delivery fleets.
The specific violation: Vehicle wraps displaying non-sponsor logos (e.g., a local bakery truck with a mascot, a produce distributor with a non-approved fruit brand).
The 'Hard Freeze' for all stadium logistics is tonight at 11:59 PM. After that, the perimeter is sealed.
Local rental agencies (Enterprise, Penske) in San Jose and Santa Clara report a complete run on unbranded white cargo vans.
NFL 'Brand Protection' officers are stationed alongside security at the delivery gates.
sources_to_cite: Logistics Manager for a stadium concessionaire (anonymous)
Leaked memo: 'Vehicle Brand Neutrality Standards for SB60'
Security staff at Gate A (loading dock)
Rental agency counter staff in San Jose
key_quotes_stats: "I have 4,000 pounds of brisket sitting in a lot in Sunnyvale because my truck has a picture of a cow on it that isn't an official sponsor."
"They told us to duct tape the logo or turn around. We don't have enough tape for a 53-foot trailer."
"It's the 'White Van Scramble'. If you have a plain white truck right now, you can charge triple."
counter_arguments_to_address: "Why didn't they plan for this?" (Rebuttal: The enforcement interpretation changed 24 hours ago to include 'transient vehicles' not just static displays).
"Can't they just deliver at night?" (Rebuttal: The checkpoints are 24/7 and the brand rules never sleep).
related_topics_for_context: Official Sponsor Exclusivity (Pepsi/Frito-Lay vs. Local Brands)
